questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after suddenly becoming unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?
questions.explanation:
System

Key Changes

Thermoregulatory

Hyperthermia (>40°C), cellular necrosis at extreme temperatures

Neurological

Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma (cerebral hypoperfusion, inflammation)

Cardiovascular

Tachycardia, hypotension, distributive shock (vasodilation, vascular leakage)

Metabolic

Acidosis (anaerobic metabolism), electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia)

Renal

AKI (rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, tubular necrosis)

Respiratory

Tachypnea, Kussmaul breathing (severe acidosis)

Hematological

Endothelial damage, microthrombosis, DIC

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and necrotic tissue, as seen in the image, are noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases

options.label: B
options.text: Urinary diversion is the next step

options.label: C
options.text: A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.correct_answer: D. Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition
  • Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph below.

options.label: A
options.text: A-Glucose, B-РАН, С- Bicarbonate and D - Inulin

options.label: B
options.text: A-Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin and D - PAH

options.label: C
options.text: A-PAH, B-Inulin, C- Glucose and D - Bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: A-Inulin, B- Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D PAH

questions.correct_answer: B. A-Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin and D - PAH
questions.explanation:
Substance

Clearance

Key Feature

A (Glucose)

Zero

Fully reabsorbed in the proximal tubule; not excreted in urine.

B (Bicarbonate)

Less than GFR

Mostly reabsorbed by the kidneys, resulting in lower clearance than GFR.

C (Inulin)

Equal to GFR

Filtered but neither reabsorbed nor secreted; ideal for measuring GFR.

D (PAH)

Greater than GFR

Filtered and actively secreted; clearance exceeds GFR.

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought with bony deformities, as shown in the radiograph below. These could be due to a deficiency of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Bone disorder characterized by failure of normal mineralisation

Etiology
  • Vitamin D deficiency: Decreased intake, malabsorption syndromes
  • Impaired Vitamin D metabolism: Hepatic and Renal causes
  • Defective Phosphates absorption:
    • Hypophosphataemic Rickets (X-linked dominant)
    • Fanconi syndrome
    • Renal tubular acidosis

Clinical features
  • Craniotabes: pin-pong ball sensation of skull bone
  • Rachitic rosary: Painless prominence of costochondral junctions
  • Harrison sulcus: horizontal depression on the lower part of chest
  • Pigeon chest: Prominent sternum
  • Deformities: Knock knees, bow legs
  • Muscular hypotonia
  • Delayed teeth eruption

Radiographic features
  • Delayed appearance of epiphysis
  • Widening of epiphyseal plates
  • Cupping of metaphysis
  • Splaying: irregular ends of metaphyseal plates
  • Refraction of diaphyseal cortex
  • Deformities: Genu varum, Genu valgum, Windswept deformity (Genu varum + valgum)

Treatment
  • Medical: Vitamin D supplementation 6 Lakh IU single dose followed by 400 IU daily.
  • Non-operative: Splints, orthopaedic shoes
  • Surgical: Corrective osteotomies > 6 months of age

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below.
questions.explanation:
Simple diffusion (Option A ruled out)

Facilitated diffusion (Option B)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm).

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury, and his serum K + level was found to be 6.5 mEq/L. What will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: First becomes more positive then negative

questions.explanation:
Condition

Hyperkalemia

Hypokalemia

RMP

Depolarized (Decreased RMP)

Hyperpolarized (Increased RMP)

Explanation
  • Increased extracellular potassium reduces the gradient for potassium to exit the cell, causing depolarization.
  • The resting membrane potential becomes less negative than the typical -70 mV. (Option C) (Options A & D ruled out)
  • In hypokalemia, cells lose more potassium ions due to leaky channels.
  • The loss of positive charge increases the negative charge within the cell, causing hyperpolarization. (Option B ruled out)

Effect on Neuron Excitability
  • Increased excitability can lead to spontaneous firing and even cell death.
  • Persistent depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing action potential generation.
  • Decreased excitability occurs as the membrane potential is further from the threshold for action potential.
  • Hypokalemia also inhibits the Na-K-ATPase pump.

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient?

What findings would be observed in a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury due to a road traffic accident, whereby the fracture fragment has penetrated the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of fine motor movement of fingers

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Sensory Modalities

Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System
  • Touch: Provides precise localization and fine gradations of intensity.
  • Vibration: Detects rapid changes in stimulus through phasic sensations.
  • Proprioception: Contributes to the sense of body position and movement.
  • Pressure: Allows for the perception of fine degrees of pressure intensity.

Pathway

Sensory receptors → Spinal cord (dorsal roots) → Brain (somatosensory cortex)

Neurons

First-order neurons
  • Originate in mechanoreceptors, and enter spinal cord via dorsal roots
  • Pseudo-unipolar neurons with cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion
  • Split into medial and lateral branches:
    • Medial branch: Travels up dorsal column to brain
    • Lateral branch: Synapses in dorsal horn, forming local reflexes, spinocerebellar tracts
  • Fibers from lower thoracic, sacral, and lumbar regions (T7-T12, L, S) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus gracilis
  • Fibers from cervical and upper thoracic regions (C, T1-T6) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus cuneatus (Option C)

Second-order neurons
  • Synapse in dorsal medulla (cuneate nucleus for upper body, gracile nucleus for lower body)
  • Cross to opposite brain stem side, travel to thalamus (medial lemniscus)

Third-order neurons
  • Synapse in thalamus (ventrobasal complex)
  • Project to somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus, lateral parietal cortex)

questions.text: A woman presents with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.explanation:
Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, and metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis.

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR):
  • ER-positive = better prognosis, responsive to endocrine therapy.
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

(Option A)

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially a worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?

options.label: B
options.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.correct_answer: B. Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
questions.explanation:
Definition

A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments.

Etiology
  • Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments.
  • Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral.

Anatomy

Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella.

Types

Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre,

  • Type I: Inferior pole of patella.
  • Type II: Lateral margin.
  • Type III: Superolateral (most common).

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment.

MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.

Differential Diagnosis

Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures).

Management
  • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
  • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.text: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.correct_answer: D. Carpal tunnel syndrome, Durkan's test
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist, Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion.
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms.
  • Durkan test: Direct compression on Median nerve for 30 seconds. More specific than the Phalen/Tinel test.

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

Conditions

Biochemical Role of Thiamine

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

 

Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function

CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations.

Wet Beriberi

Thiamine is necessary for the PDH complex and low activity causes Lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis causes vasodilatation and hence cardiovascular manifestations.

Cardiovascular manifestations such as oedema, palpitations, breathlessness, and heart failure.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

 

Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids

Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

Lactic Acidosis

 

Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA

Impaired conversion leads to increased lactate and pyruvate levels, causing lactic acidosis.

A patient with a previous MI and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Amiodarone

Mechanism of Action
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple color (Purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Drug Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had an arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord.
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonos- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonos- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

Treatment
  • Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room.
  • Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow.
  • Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable.
  • Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions.
  • Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects.

Autopsy Findings
  • Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately and passes off early.
  • Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found.
  • Delayed putrefaction.
  • Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera; brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis.

Differentiating Points

Strychnine Poisoning

Tetanus

1. History

History of poisoning

History of injury

2. Onset

Sudden onset

Gradual onset

3. Convulsions/Spasms

Generalized convulsions

Lockjaw (trismus)

4. Chest Movement

Chest fixed during convulsions

Not typically fixed

5. Relaxation Between Spasms

Complete relaxation between seizures

Relaxation between spasms is never complete

6. Duration Until Fatality

Ends fatally within a few hours

Death is rare within a few hours

7. Chemical Evidence

Chemical analysis reveals the poison

No specific chemical detection

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Alkali causes liquefaction, saponification, and thrombosis of vessels, leading to fibrosis and stricture.
  • Acid causes intense pylorospasm, antral pooling, coagulation necrosis, and eschar formation.

Acute Phase Management
  • Neutralization: vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid
  • Early endoscopy to assess severity and extent
  • Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation

Management by Burn Degree

1st Degree Burns:

  • 48 hours observation; oral feeds resumed once saliva is swallowed painlessly
  • Regular follow-up endoscopy at 1st, 2nd, and 8th months to identify stricture

2nd & 3rd Degree Burns:

  • Fluid therapy, antibiotics, nutrition, PPIs and aerosolised steroids and resuscitation
  • Fiberoptic-guided airway intubation/tracheostomy, if necessary.
  • Endoscopic esophageal stenting, jejunostomy for feeding.
  • Laparoscopy for evaluation; laparotomy in unstable patients
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness.
  • Consider re-exploration after 36-48 hours if necessary.
  • Regular endoscopic dilatation for stricture
  • Use of various dilators (e.g., balloon, Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow) for esophageal dilatation.

Surgical Considerations
  • Esophageal resection is technically difficult; bypass may be preferred
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • A colonic conduit may be used if the stomach is diseased
  • Multiple strictures may require esophageal resection and colonic transposition

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Alkaptonuria

Definition

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD), an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway.

Mechanism and Pathophysiology

Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis).

 

  • Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate.
  • Consequences:
    • HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis).
    • Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy.
  • Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA).
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis.
  • Cardiac: Aortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease.
  • Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate).
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, stroke.

Evaluation
  • Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI).
  • Diagnostic tests:
    • Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.
    • Genetic testing for HGD mutations.
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities.

Management
  • Symptomatic: Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery.
  • Diet: Low-protein diet (limited efficacy).
  • Medications:
    • Vitamin C: Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion.
    • Nitisinone: Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.

Prognosis and Complications
  • Prognosis: Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability).
  • Complications:
    • Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary).
    • Tendon/ligament ruptures.
    • Osteopenia, fractures.
    • Aortic calcification/stenosis.

options.text: Internal oblique B) External oblique C) Parietal peritoneum D) Fascia transversalis

questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

(Option C)

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent.

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle (Option A)

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle (Option B)

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.explanation:
Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves.
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
    • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
    • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was prescribed drug A after he did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine. He now presents with excessive salivation, an increase in blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia. What is drug “A”?
questions.explanation:
Clozapine

Class

Atypical antipsychotic (1st atypical antipsychotic discovered)

Mechanism of action

Primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Uses

  • DOC for TRS (Treatment-resistant schizophrenia): Used only when a patient doesn't respond to at least 2 antipsychotics.
  • Only antipsychotics with anti-suicidal properties (shown ↓ suicidal ideas in Schizophrenia patients).

Side effects

Severe risks (Pneumonic: SAM):

  • S - Seizures
    • Dose dependant
    • > 600 mg has more seizures
  • A - Agranulocytosis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • ↓ WBC (Neutrophils)
    • The main reason for deaths and withdrawal from the market
    • Weekly monitoring of WBC and Neutrophil count for 1st 6 months is important
  • M - Myocarditis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • Chest pain
    • Dyspnea
    • Abnormal ECG

Common side effects:

  • Sedation (most common)
  • Weight gain (maximum weight gain of all antipsychotics)
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea)
  • Sedation
  • Tachycardia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension

Rare side effects include myocarditis.

Contraindications

  • WBC count - < 3500/mm
  • Previous bone marrow disorder
  • H/o of Agranulocytosis during Clozapine treatment
  • Use of another bone marrow suppressant (carbamazepine)

Monitoring

TLC and ANC

  • Once a week for the first 6 months
  • Once in two weeks for the next 6 months
  • Once a month till the patient continues

(Option B)

Postpartum Depression

(Option A)

(Option C)

Timing

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months.

Symptoms

Transient symptoms such as:

  • Emotionally labile
  • Insomnia
  • Weepiness/tearfulness
  • Loss of energy
  • Depressed mood
  • Loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia)
  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal thoughts

Initial symptoms: insomnia, tearfulness, mood lability, fatigue, followed by:

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions

Risk Factors

Not specific; linked to biochemical changes.
  • Young maternal age
  • Antenatal depression
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Unmarried status
  • Smoking
  • Stress
  • Newborns in intensive care
  • Physical or verbal abuse
  • Serious adverse obstetrical events
  • Nulliparas
  • Obstetrical complications
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • History of psychotic illness

Treatment

Supportive treatment and reassurance.

Antidepressants and psychotherapy.
  • Hospitalization, pharmacological treatment (lithium, antipsychotics, antidepressants), and long-term psychiatric care.
  • Temporary separation from the infant and nursing supervision may be necessary.

questions.explanation:
Aspects

Auricle (Pinna)

External Auditory Meatus

Composition

Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue)
  • Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands
  • Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands.

Parts
  • Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus)
  • Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs)
  • Antihelix (Parallel ridge to the helix)
  • Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch)
  • Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix)
  • Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus)

Nerve Supply

Lateral Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve)

 

Medial Surface

  • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
  • Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

 

Clinical Relevance

McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae)

  • It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum.

A pediatric patient presents with cola-coloured urine, high blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory tests reveal a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which rises to 4.5 mg/dL after 3 weeks despite treatment. What electron microscopic finding is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Mitral Regurgitation

Type

Cause

Features of Murmur

Associated Symptoms

Mitral Regurgitation (MR)

Incomplete closure of the mitral valve, causing backflow from LV to LA.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla.
  • Intensity: Grade II-IV, soft/absent S1 in chronic cases.

Dyspnea, fatigue, orthopnea, atrial fibrillation.

Aortic Regurgitation (AR) (Option B)

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve, causing retrograde flow into LV.
  • Type: Diastolic decrescendo murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at left sternal border (3rd-4th ICS).
  • Features: High-pitched, decrescendo.

Bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, Water-Hammer pulse, heart failure symptoms.

Aortic Stenosis (AS) (Option C)

Narrowing of the aortic valve, obstructing LV outflow.
  • Type: Systolic ejection murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at right upper sternal border (2nd ICS), radiates to carotids.
  • Features: Crescendo-decrescendo.

Angina, syncope, left ventricular hypertrophy, paradoxical S2 splitting.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) (Option D)

Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing flow from LA to LV.
  • Type: Diastolic rumbling murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at apex in left lateral decubitus position.
  • Features: Low-pitched, with an opening snap after S2.

Dyspnea, pulmonary hypertension, right-sided heart failure, atrial fibrillation.

Definition

Abnormal heart sounds caused by turbulent blood flow through valves or cardiac chambers.

Classification
  • Systolic Murmurs: Occur between S1 and S2 (e.g., MR, AS).
  • Diastolic Murmurs: Occur between S2 and S1 (e.g., MS, AR).
  • Continuous Murmurs: Occur throughout the cardiac cycle (e.g., PDA).

Clinical Assessment

Includes murmur timing, intensity, location, radiation, and associated cardiac or systemic features.

Grading System (Intensity)
  • Grade I: Barely audible.
  • Grade II: Soft but easily audible.
  • Grade III: Loud without thrill.
  • Grade IV: Loud with a palpable thrill.
  • Grade V: Very loud, audible with edge of stethoscope.
  • Grade VI: Audible without a stethoscope.

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to:

options.label: B
options.text: Years lost due to premature death

options.label: D
options.text: Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.correct_answer: B. Years lost due to premature death
questions.explanation:
Crude death rate

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken on 1st July
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population

Age-specific death rate

ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000

Expectation of life

 

 
  • Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community.
  • Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years.

Infant mortality rate

IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator.

Under-five mortality rate

U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000

Maternal Mortality Rate

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000

 

Adult mortality rate

Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life

Year of potential life lost

Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost

Proportional mortality rate

The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community)́ x 100

Case fatality rate

CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100

Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY)

(Option D ruled out)
  • Quality and quantity of life lived.
  • Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention
  • QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health
  • Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention.
  • Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health).

Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY)

(Option C ruled out)
  • DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability
  • 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost
  • It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention
     

Year of life lost (YLL):

  • Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy.
     

Years lost to disability (YLD):

  • Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead).

 

DALY = YLL + YLD

Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE)
  • The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate.
    Healthy Life Expectancy
    • HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health
    • HALE = LE-DALY

Life Expectancy

  • Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate.

Sullivan’s index
(or DFLE)
  • Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Ankylosing Spondylitis

Ankylosing Spondylitis - Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.

Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Tests

X-rays

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints, such as:

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

 

Disease

Radiographic Abnormalities

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
  • Periarticular osteoporosis, joint subluxation, marginal erosions, joint space narrowing, osteoporosis, osteopenia, and vertebral fractures.
  • Ulnar Deviation, swelling of Synovial Tissue​

Paget’s Disease
  • Bone expansion, abnormal trabecular pattern.

Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA)
  • Sacroiliitis, syndesmophytes, bone sclerosis.
  • Pencil-in-cup deformity

Osteoarthritis (OA)
  • Joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, fractures, cortical thinning, osteosclerosis, lysis, pseudofractures, proliferative enthesis erosions, enthesophytes, joint deformity, subchondral cysts.
  • Heberden’s Nodes (involvement of DIP), Bouchard’s Nodes​ (involvement of PIP)

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)
  • Joint fusion, syndesmophytes, sacroiliitis, spinal ligament calcification.
  • Bamboo Spine, Shiny Corner Sign, Squaring of Vertebrae​

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
  • Joint space narrowing, periarticular osteoporosis, subchondral cysts, calcinosis cutis.
  • Destructive arthritis, erosions in later stages.

Gout
  • Acute inflammation, joint space narrowing, cortical erosions.
  • Tophus (urate crystal deposits in soft tissue).
  • Martel G sign: Also known as rat-bite erosions (lytic lesions with sclerotic margin & overhanging edge)

Scleroderma
  • Calcinosis cutis, soft tissue calcifications, joint space narrowing.
  • Ray Sign (involvement of small joints of hands).

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - IV Mannitol:

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this?
questions.explanation:
Causative agent
  • Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus
  • Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months

Clinical features
  • Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here
  • No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis
  • One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins
  • Two-stick stage: will need crutches
  • Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in.

Treatment
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day
  • Banning the crop

Toxin removal
  • Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried.
  • Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater.
  • Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same.
  • Educating people.
  • Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Diltiazem

Thyrotoxic crisis or thyroid storm

It is a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Delirium, seizures, coma
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Jaundice
  • Hyperthermia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Arrhythmias

Precipitating factors

Precipitating factors:

Stress:

  • Acute illnesses like stroke, trauma, diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Surgery, commonly of the thyroid

Infections

Acute iodine load:

  • Radioiodine treatment of a patient with partially or untreated hyperthyroidism
  • Iodinated contrast agents
  • Amiodarone administeration

Treatment

  • Management of the precipitating factors (digoxin, diuretics, & oxygen)
  • IV fluids and ice pack
  • Propylthiouracil (DOC)
  • Methimazole/carbimazole
  • Beta-blockers
  • Corticosteroids
  • Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate

questions.text: An elderly male presents for a routine medical examination. Laboratory investigations reveal a very high total leukocyte count (TLC). The peripheral smear shows findings as shown in the image. What is the appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

Genetics: Trisomy 12, deletion 13q14, and others

Origin: Post–germinal centre memory B cell or naive B Cells in the mantle zone of the lymph node.

Etiopathogenesis

  • Antiapoptotic protein BCL2 overexpression.
  • CLL cell growth depends on Bruton Tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity.
  • No association with radiation exposure

Clinical Presentation

  • Most common Leukemia in the elderly.
  • Frequently asymptomatic at diagnosis.
  • May present with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or infection due to immunosuppression.
  • Associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia- spherocytes can be seen on peripheral smear
  • Can l/t Hypogammaglobulinemia( highlight )as B cells are abnormal -
  • Infection is the M/C/C of death in CLL

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) > 5000/mm3
  • Bone marrow lymphocytes >30%
  • Surface markers using flow cytometry were positive for CD5, CD23, CD19, and CD20.
    • CLL co-expresses both T cell (CD5) and B cell (CD20, CD19) markers

questions.text: Who is responsible for counseling and providing information to the patient, a 30-week primigravida experiencing reduced vision at night, who has been avoiding certain fruits during her pregnancy due to concerns about their potential abortifacient effects?
questions.explanation:
ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Promote health and sanitation practices.
  • Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  • Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  • Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  • Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  • Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

 

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

questions.text: A chronic smoker who worked in a cement factory for 20 years developed mesothelioma. It is due to?
questions.explanation:
Mesothelioma

A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura, and it can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis

Etiology

Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening,
  • making the affected side rigid and immobile
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • A mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

CT scan shows Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)

Biopsy (Diagnosis can be confirmed)

  • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
  • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.

Specific markers for mesothelioma

  • Calretinin
  • Epithelial membrane antigen
  • Cytokeratin
  • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor - median survival of 9-21 months

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Basal gang

Area of Lesion

Consequences

Frontal Lobe
  • Disinhibition and deficits in concentration, orientation, judgment
  • May have reemergence of primitive reflexes.

Frontal Eye Fields
  • Eyes look toward the lesion.

Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation
  • Eyes look away from the side of the lesion.

Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (impaired adduction of ipsilateral eye; nystagmus of contralateral eye with abduction).
  • Eg: Multiple sclerosis

Dominant Parietal Cortex
  • Gerstmann syndrome: Agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, left-right disorientation

Nondominant Parietal Cortex
  • Hemispatial neglect syndrome: Agnosia of the contralateral side of the world.

Hippocampus (Bilateral)
  • Anterograde amnesia: Inability to make new memories.

Basal Ganglia
  • May result in tremors at rest, chorea, and athetosis.
  • Eg: Parkinson disease, Huntington disease.

Subthalamic Nucleus
  • Contralateral hemiballismus.

Mammillary Bodies (Bilateral)
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, memory loss (anterograde and retrograde amnesia), confabulation, personality changes.

Amygdala (Bilateral)
  • Klüver-Bucy syndrome: Disinhibited behavior (eg, hyperphagia, hypersexuality, hyperorality).
  • Eg: HSV-1 encephalitis

Superior Colliculus
  • Parinaud syndrome: Paralysis of conjugate vertical gaze (rostral interstitial nucleus also involved).
  • Eg: Stroke, hydrocephalus, pinealoma.

Reticular Activating System (Midbrain)
  • Reduced levels of arousal and wakefulness (eg, coma).

Cerebellar Hemisphere
  • Intention tremor, limb ataxia, loss of balance; damage to cerebellum → Ipsilateral deficits; fall toward side of lesion.
  • (Cerebellar hemispheres are laterally located and affect lateral limbs)

Cerebellar Vermis
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Dysarthria
  • (Vermis is centrally located and affects central body)

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.correct_answer: D. Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL
questions.explanation:
Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a small nodule on the sclera as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description

Staghorn Calculus

 

Putty Kidney (Option A)

Medullary Nephrocalcinosis

Description

Large, branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the shape of a staghorn.

Tissue damage in the kidney by TB leads to dystrophic calcification. Indicates end-stage renal TB.

Calcium deposition within the renal medulla (inner kidney).

Cause

Struvite stones formed from magnesium ammonium phosphate due to infection with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Klebsiella, Proteus)

Renal tuberculosis leads to granuloma formation causing necrosis, cavitation, fibrosis and stricture formation.

Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, renal tubular acidosis, medullary sponge kidney disease) leading to calcification of the renal medulla

Imaging Characteristics

Radio-opaque, visible on CT. They often form rapidly; fill the renal pelvis and extend into calyces. (Option B ruled out)

Appears as a lobulated mass of calcified tissue on CT scans, resembling "putty"; indicating a non-functioning kidney.

Detected on plain radiographs, ultrasound, and CT. USG and CT are very specific and hence useful even in mild cases

  • USG- hyperechoic renal parenchyma with posterior acoustic shadowing.

 

  • CT- High-density renal parenchyma in the medulla (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Features of Murmur

Associated Symptoms

JVP Findings

Aortic Regurgitation (AR)

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve, causing retrograde flow into LV.
  • Type: Diastolic decrescendo murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at left sternal border (3rd-4th ICS).
  • Features: High-pitched, decrescendo.
  • Bounding pulses
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Water-Hammer pulse
  • Heart failure symptoms.

Normal or minimally elevated JVP unless associated with heart failure.

Aortic Stenosis (AS)

Narrowing of the aortic valve, obstructing LV outflow.
  • Type: Systolic ejection murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at right upper sternal border (2nd ICS), radiates to carotids.
  • Features: Crescendo-decrescendo.
  • Angina
  • Syncope
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Paradoxical S2 splitting.

Normal JVP unless severe.

Mitral Regurgitation (MR) (Option C)

Incomplete closure of the mitral valve, causing backflow from LV to LA.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla.
  • Intensity: Grade II-IV, soft/absent S1 in chronic cases.
  • Dyspnea
  • Fatigue
  • Orthopnea
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP, prominent V wave due to regurgitant flow.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) (Option A)

Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing flow from LA to LV.
  • Type: Diastolic rumbling murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at apex in left lateral decubitus position.
  • Features: Low-pitched, with an opening snap after S2.
  • Dyspnea
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Right-sided heart failure
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) (Option D)

Incomplete closure of the tricuspid valve, causing backflow into the right atrium.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Holosystolic, blowing murmur.
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Edema
  • Right-sided heart failure.

Elevated JVP with prominent "v" wave due to backflow into the right atrium.

Tricuspid Stenosis (TS)

Narrowing of the tricuspid valve, obstructing flow from RA to RV.
  • Type: Diastolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Low-pitched rumbling murmur.
  • Fatigue
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Peripheral edema.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

Murmur Type

Subtype

Conditions murmur heard

Additional points

Systolic Murmurs

Ejection Systolic Murmur

(HAPpy)
  • Pulmonary Stenosis
  • Aortic Stenosis
  • HOCM
  • Early systolic murmur seen with papillary muscle dysfunction.
  • Late systolic murmur is seen in small VSD and mitral valve prolapse (MVP)

Pan Systolic Murmur(MTV)
  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Ventricular septal defect

Diastolic Murmurs

Early Diastolic Murmur (GAP)
  • Graham Steell murmur
  • Aortic regurgitation (mild)
  • Pulmonary regurgitation (mild)
  • Along with hemodynamic changes the characteristics of flow also changes

Mid-Diastolic Murmur
  • Carey Coombs murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur
  • Mitral stenosis
  • Flow murmur may mimic mid-diastolic murmur

Continuous Murmurs

 
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Aortopulmonary window
  • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
  • Coronary arteriovenous fistula
  • Cervical venous hum
  • Anomalous left coronary artery origin
  • Mammary souffle of pregnancy
  • Bronchial collateral circulation
  • Intercostal or pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
  • Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Causes are diverse and involve persistent communication between systemic and pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Regular Astigmatism
  • Refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. There are 2 principal meridians.
    • Oblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not horizontal and vertical but are at right angles to each other (e.g., 45° and 135°).
    • Bioblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other (e.g., one at 30° and the other at 100°).

Irregular Astigmatism
  • Irregular change in refractive power in different meridians, with multiple meridians that do not admit geometrical analysis

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? RBS 550 mg/dL pH 7.01 Na+ 158 mEq/L Urine glucose 3+

options.label: A
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: C
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: D
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.correct_answer: A. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
questions.explanation:
DKA Management in Children

Immediate Management (First Hour):

Rapid Assessment:
  • Evaluate the child's vital signs (heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure) and weight.
  • Assess GCS and check for signs of dehydration.
  • Obtain blood samples for urgent measurement of blood glucose, blood beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) if available, venous pH, electrolytes (including bicarbonate), serum urea nitrogen, and creatinine.
  • Serum BHB concentration: Most precise approach to measuring the severity of DKA

Establish IV Access:

Place two large-bore peripheral IV lines. Central lines are generally avoided (risk of thrombosis) unless necessary.

Initial Fluid Resuscitation

Administer a bolus of 0.9% saline at a rate of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and address dehydration.

After First Hour

Initiate Insulin Therapy

Start an intravenous insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 U/kg/h, typically one hour after initiating fluids.

Continue Fluid Therapy

 

After the initial bolus, continue fluid replacement with 0.45% to 0.9% saline, to replace the estimated fluid deficit over 24 to 48 hours. Adjust fluids based on clinical status and laboratory values.

Monitoring and Replacing Electrolytes
  • Begin potassium replacement once urine output is confirmed as insulin causes K+ entry into cells, leading to hypokalemia.
  • Monitor vital signs, GCS, fluid balance, and capillary blood glucose every hour.
  • Reassess electrolytes, blood glucose, blood urea nitrogen, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, blood gases, and BOHB every two hours if available.

Transition Phase (6-24 Hours):

Gradual Reduction of IV Fluids and

transition to subcutaneous Insulin

 
  • As DKA resolves and the child can tolerate oral intake, gradually reduce IV fluids while maintaining hydration.
  • Transition to subcutaneous insulin once pH > 7.30, bicarbonate > 18 mmol/L, and BOHB < 1 mmol/L.
  • Administer the first subcutaneous insulin dose 15-30 minutes before discontinuing the IV insulin infusion.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Dementia

Description

Clinical Findings

Alzheimer's Disease (AD) (Option D)

Most common type of dementia, characterized by amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain.
  • Memory loss, especially short-term memory
  • Disorientation
  • Language difficulties
  • Impaired judgment and reasoning
  • Personality changes
  • Progressive cognitive decline2

Vascular Dementia

Results from damage to blood vessels in the brain, leading to reduced blood flow. Often follows a stroke or series of small strokes.
  • Stepwise progression of cognitive decline
  • Memory loss
  • Impaired executive function
  • Gait disturbances
  • Personality and mood changes
  • Signs of previous strokes (e.g., hemiparesis)

Lewy Body Dementia

Caused by abnormal protein deposits (Lewy bodies) in the brain, affecting cognitive and motor functions.
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity)
  • Cognitive fluctuations
  • Memory impairment
  • REM sleep behavior disorder

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)

Characterized by degeneration in the frontal and temporal lobes, often with personality and behavioral changes.
  • Personality and behavior changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy)
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Lack of empathy
  • Impulsive behaviors
  • Social withdrawal

Mixed Dementia

A combination of Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. Common in elderly patients.
  • Symptoms of both Alzheimer's and vascular dementia
  • Cognitive decline with stepwise progression
  • Memory problems
  • Behavioral changes
  • Motor problems (e.g., gait disturbances)

Parkinson's Disease Dementia

Occurs in patients with Parkinson's disease, typically years after motor symptoms begin.
  • Memory loss
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Attention deficits
  • Executive dysfunction
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor)

Huntington's Disease

(Option C)

Genetic disorder characterized by progressive motor, cognitive, and psychiatric decline.
  • Involuntary movements (chorea)
  • Memory impairment
  • Personality changes (e.g., irritability, depression)
  • Impaired coordination and motor function
  • Progressive dementia

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)

(Option B)

Rare prion disease causing rapid neurodegeneration, often with fatal progression.
  • Rapid onset of dementia
  • Motor symptoms (e.g., ataxia, myoclonus)
  • Visual disturbances
  • Psychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression)
  • Death usually within 1-2 years

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome

Caused by thiamine deficiency, often due to alcohol abuse. Can lead to brain damage and dementia.
  • Amnesia (anterograde and retrograde)
  • Confabulation
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Neurological abnormalities due to thiamine deficiency

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

A condition where excess cerebrospinal fluid accumulates in the brain ventricles, leading to cognitive decline.
  • Gait disturbances (shuffling walk)
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Enlargement of the ventricles on brain imaging

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an infant brought in with symptoms of excessive tear production, sensitivity to light, and blepharospasm?
questions.explanation:
Primary Congenital Glaucoma

Types

1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. (40% cases)

Typically presents within the first month of life.

Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions.

2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age- Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday

Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years.

Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations.

3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age.

Buphthalmos, meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP.
  • Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum.
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features

Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.

Corneal Signs:

  • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
  • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.

Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.

Additional Features:

  • Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
  • Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages.
  • Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
  • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
  • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.
